pli-tv-kd8:1.33.13: The Buddha had a hot bath.
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.14: When he had bathed, the Buddha was purged once,
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.15: in total adding up to thirty purgings.
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.16: And Jīvaka said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.17: “Sir, until your body is back to normal, please don’t take any mung-bean broth.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.18.0: The account of asking for a favor
pli-tv-kd8:1.33.18.1: Soon the Buddha’s body was back to normal.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.1: Jīvaka then took those two valuable cloths and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.3: “Venerable Sir, I wish to ask for a favor.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.6: “Well then, please say what it is.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.7: “The Buddha and the Sangha of monks are rag-robe wearers.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.8: But I’ve received these two valuable cloths from King Pajjota
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.9: that are extremely exquisite and fine—they are one in a million.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.11: and please allow the Sangha of monks to use robe-cloth given by householders.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.12: The Buddha received the two valuable cloths.
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.13: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Jīvaka with a teaching,
pli-tv-kd8:1.34.14: after which Jīvaka got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.2: “Monks, I allow you to use robe-cloth given by householders.

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.4: and anyone who wishes may accept robe-cloth from householders.
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.5: But I praise contentment with whatever sort you use.”
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.7: that the Buddha had allowed the monks to use robe-cloth given by householders.
pli-tv-kd8:1.35.8: They were excited and joyful, thinking,

pli-tv-kd8:1.35.11: And the same thing happened in the countryside.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.1: A fleecy robe was given to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.2: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.4: And a silken fleecy robe was given.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.7: And a woolen fleecy robe was given.
pli-tv-kd8:1.36.10: The first section for recitation is finished.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.0: Discussion on the allowance for wool
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.1: On one occasion the King of Kāsī sent a valuable, woolen Kāsī-cloth to Jīvaka.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.2: Jīvaka took the cloth and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.3: and told him what had happened,
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.5: adding, “Sir, please accept the woolen cloth for my long-lasting benefit and happiness.”
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.6: The Buddha received the woolen cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.7: He then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Jīvaka with a teaching,
pli-tv-kd8:2.1.8: after which Jīvaka got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.

pli-tv-kd8:3.1.1: At that time various kinds of robe-cloth were given to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.3: “What kinds of robe-cloth has the Buddha allowed and what has he not allowed?”
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:3.1.6: linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp.”
pli-tv-kd8:3.2.1: Soon afterwards the monks thought, “The Buddha has only allowed one kind of robe, not two,”
pli-tv-kd8:3.2.2: and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept rags after receiving robe-cloth from householders.
pli-tv-kd8:3.2.4: “I allow you to accept rags after receiving robe-cloth from a householder.
pli-tv-kd8:3.2.5: But I praise contentment with both of them.”
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.1: On one occasion a number of monks were traveling in the Kosalan country.
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.2: Some of the monks entered a charnel ground to look for rags, while the others walked on.
pli-tv-kd8:4.1.8: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.2.1: On another occasion a number of monks were traveling in the Kosalan country.
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.2: Some of the monks entered a charnel ground to look for rags, while the others waited.
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.7: “But why didn’t you come with us, then?
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.8: We won’t give you a share.”
pli-tv-kd8:4.2.10: “Even if you’re unwilling, you should give a share to those who wait.”
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.1: On yet another occasion a number of monks were traveling in the Kosalan country.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.2: Some of the monks entered a charnel ground to look for rags first, while the other monks entered afterwards.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.3: Those who entered first obtained rags,
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.4: but not those who entered afterwards.
pli-tv-kd8:4.3.8: “But why, then, did you come in afterwards?

pli-tv-kd8:4.3.11: “If you’re unwilling, I allow you not to give a share to those who enter afterwards.”
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.1: On yet another occasion a number of monks were traveling in the Kosalan country.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.2: They all entered a charnel ground together to look for rags.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.3: Some of them obtained rags, while others did not.
pli-tv-kd8:4.4.8: We won’t give you a share.”

pli-tv-kd8:4.5.2: They entered a charnel ground together to look for rags, after making an agreement to share.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.3: Some of them obtained rags, while others did not.
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.8: We won’t give you a share.”
pli-tv-kd8:4.5.10: “Even if you’re unwilling, if you have made an agreement about it, you should give a share to those who enter.”
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.0: Discussion on the appointment of a receiver of robe-cloth
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.1: At that time people brought robe-cloth to the monastery,
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.2: but not finding anyone to receive it, they took it back.
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.3: As a result, only a little robe-cloth was given at that monastery.
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.5: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the receiver of robe-cloth:
pli-tv-kd8:5.1.6: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been received.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.1: And this is how he should be appointed.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.2: First a monk should be asked,
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.3: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.7: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.8: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.9: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.10: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.11: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the receiver of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:5.2.12: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.1: Soon afterwards, after receiving cloth, the receivers of robe-cloth left it right there and went away.
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.4: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the storer of robe-cloth:
pli-tv-kd8:6.1.5: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what is and is not stored.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.1: And this is how he should be appointed.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.2: First a monk should be asked,
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.3: and then a competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the storer of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.7: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.8: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the storer of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.9: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the storer of robe-cloth should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.10: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.11: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the storer of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:6.2.12: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.0: Discussion on the designation of a storeroom, etc.
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.1: Soon afterwards the monk who was the storer of robe-cloth stored it under a roof-cover, at the foot of a tree, and under the eaves of a building. Rats and termites ate it.
pli-tv-kd8:7.1.3: “I allow you to designate a dwelling, a stilt house, or a cave as a storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.1: And this is how it should be designated.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.2: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.4: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should designate such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.6: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.7: The Sangha designates such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.8: Any monk who approves of designating such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.9: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.10: The Sangha has designated such-and-such a dwelling as a storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:7.2.11: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.1: At that time the robe-cloth in the Sangha’s storeroom was not looked after.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.3: “You should appoint a monk who has five qualities as the storeman: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what is and is not protected.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.4: And this is how he should be appointed.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.5: First a monk should be asked,

pli-tv-kd8:8.1.7: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.8: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the storeman.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.10: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.11: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the storeman.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.12: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the storeman should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.13: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:8.1.14: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the storeman.

pli-tv-kd8:8.2.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.1: At one time there was much robe-cloth in the Sangha’s storeroom.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.3: “You should share it out in the presence of the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.4: Soon afterwards there was a racket as the Sangha was sharing out the robe-cloth.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.7: he is not swayed by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear, and he knows what has and has not been distributed.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.8: And this is how he should be appointed.

pli-tv-kd8:9.1.12: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.14: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.15: The Sangha appoints monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.16: Any monk who approves of appointing monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.17: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.18: The Sangha has appointed monk so-and-so as the distributor of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:9.1.19: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.1: The monks who were distributors of robe-cloth thought,
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.4: “You should first sort the cloth, then estimate its value, followed by making portions of equal value, counting the monks, gathering the monks into groups, and finally fixing the shares of robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.5: And the monks who were distributors of robe-cloth thought,
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.6: “What share of the robe-cloth should we give to the novices?”
pli-tv-kd8:9.2.8: “I allow you to give half a share to the novices.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.1: On one occasion a monk wanted to take his own share and depart.
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.3: “You should give a share to one who is departing.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.4: On another occasion a monk wanted to take an extra share and depart.
pli-tv-kd8:9.3.6: “I allow you to give an extra share to anyone who gives something in return.”
pli-tv-kd8:9.4.1: And the distributors of robe-cloth thought,
pli-tv-kd8:9.4.2: “How should we give out the shares of robe-cloth? According to the order in which the monks have arrived or according to seniority?”
pli-tv-kd8:9.4.4: “You should share out the remainder and then give it out by drawing lots.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.0: Discussion on the dyeing of robes
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.1: At that time the monks dyed the robes even with dung and beige clay.
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.4: “I allow you to use six kinds of dye:
pli-tv-kd8:10.1.5: dye from roots, dye from wood, dye from bark, dye from leaves, dye from flowers, and dye from fruit.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.1: At that time the monks dyed the robes in cold water.
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.4: “I allow a dye-pot to boil the dye.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.7: “I allow you to fix a collar.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.8: The monks did not know whether the dye was ready or not.
pli-tv-kd8:10.2.10: “You should put a drop in water or on the back of your nail.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.1: To remove the dye, the monks turned the pot.
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.4: “I allow a dye-ladle, with or without handle.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.5: The monks did not have a vessel for the dye.
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.7: “I allow a basin for dye, a waterpot for dye.”
pli-tv-kd8:10.3.8: The monks were kneading the robes in basins and bowls.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.1: At that time the monks spread the robes on the ground.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.5: The straw mat was eaten by termites.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.7: “I allow a bamboo robe-rack and a clothesline.”
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.8: They hung up the robes by the middle.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.9: The dye dripped from both sides.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.11: “You should fasten it at the corners.”
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.14: “I allow you thread for the corners.”
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.15: The dye dripped from one side.
pli-tv-kd8:11.1.17: “You should dye it by repeatedly turning it over, and you should not go away while it’s still dripping.”
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.6: “You should beat it with your hands.”
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.7: At that time the monks wore robes consisting of a single piece of cloth, the color of ivory.
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.9: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.10: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.11: “You should not wear robes made consisting of a single piece of cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:11.2.12: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.0: The instruction on robes made of pieces
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.1: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward the southern hills.
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.2: He saw the fields of Magadha laid out in rectangles defined by long and short boundaries and their intersections. He said to Venerable Ānanda,
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.3: “Ānanda, have a look at these fields.”
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.5: “Are you able to make this kind of robe for the monks?”
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.7: After staying in the southern hills for as long as he liked, the Buddha returned to Rājagaha.
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.8: Ānanda then made robes for a number of monks. He approached the Buddha and said,
pli-tv-kd8:12.1.9: “Venerable Sir, please have a look at the robes I’ve made.”
pli-tv-kd8:12.2.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:12.2.2: “Ānanda is clever. He understands the detailed meaning of what I have spoken in brief.
pli-tv-kd8:12.2.3: He can make long inter-panel strips, short inter-panel strips, large panels, medium-sized panels, middle sections, intermediate sections, a strengthening piece for the neck, a strengthening piece for the calves, and outer sections. In this way the robe will be made of pieces, making it worthless, making it appropriate for ascetics, making it undesirable for one’s enemies.
pli-tv-kd8:12.2.4: Your outer robe should be made of pieces and so should your upper robe and sarong.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.1: After staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Vesālī.
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.2: On the road between Rājagaha and Vesālī the Buddha saw a number of monks walking along, loaded up with robes on their heads, shoulders, and hips. He thought,
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.3: “These foolish men have turned to an abundance in robes too readily.
pli-tv-kd8:13.1.4: Let me set a limit on robes for the monks.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.1: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Vesālī, where he stayed at the Gotamaka Shrine.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.2: At that time it was midwinter, when the days are cold and the snow is falling. The Buddha sat outside at night without being cold, wearing only one robe. He was fine.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.3: Becoming cold at the end of the first part of the night, he put on a second robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.4: Becoming cold once again at the end of the middle part of the night, he put on a third robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.2.5: At the end of the last part of the night, when the sky was flaring up at dawn, he became cold once more. Putting on a fourth robe, he was fine.
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.1: He thought, “Even those on this spiritual path who come from good families, who are sensitive to the cold and fear the cold, are able to get by with three robes.
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.2: Let me set a limit on robes for the monks; let me allow them three robes.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.3.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks.
pli-tv-kd8:13.4.1: He told them what had happened
pli-tv-kd8:13.5.5: and what he had thought, adding:
pli-tv-kd8:13.5.8: “I allow you three robes: a double-layered outer robe, a single-layered upper robe, and a single-layered sarong.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.1: When they knew that the Buddha had allowed three robes,
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.2: the monks from the group of six entered the village in one set of three, stayed in the monastery in another set, and went bathing in yet another set.
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.3: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.4: “How can the monks from the group of six keep extra robes?”
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.6: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:13.6.8: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.1: Soon afterwards Venerable Ānanda was given an extra robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.2: He wanted to give it to Venerable Sāriputta
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.5: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down a rule against having an extra robe, he thought,
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.10: “What should I do in this situation?”
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.11: He told the Buddha, who said,
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.12: “How long is it, Ānanda, before Sāriputta returns?”
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.14: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:13.7.15: “You should keep an extra robe for ten days at the most.”
pli-tv-kd8:13.8.1: Soon afterwards the monks were given an extra robe.
pli-tv-kd8:13.8.3: Not knowing what to do with it,
pli-tv-kd8:13.8.4: they told the Buddha, and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:13.8.5: “I allow you to transfer extra robes to another.”
pli-tv-kd8:14.1.1: After staying at Vesālī for as long as he liked, the Buddha set out wandering toward Benares.
pli-tv-kd8:14.1.3: he stayed in the deer park at Isipattana.
pli-tv-kd8:14.1.4: On that occasion the sarong of a certain monk had a tear.
pli-tv-kd8:14.1.7: a double-layered outer robe, a single-layered upper robe, and a single-layered sarong.

pli-tv-kd8:15.7.1: “For as long as I live I wish to give rainy-season robes to the Sangha, and I wish to give meals to the newly arrived and departing monastics, as well as to those who are sick and those nursing the sick. pli-tv-kd8:15.7.2: “But, Visākhā, what reason do you have for asking me for these eight favors?”
pli-tv-kd8:15.7.3: Visākhā then told the Buddha what had happened to her slave,

pli-tv-kd8:15.8.4: Also, in trying to get a meal, departing monks may bother the Teacher, or they may arrive late at their destination. Or, if they go without eating, they will be weak while traveling.
pli-tv-kd8:15.8.5: After eating a meal for departing monks from me, they won’t bother the Teacher, they will arrive at their destination at an appropriate time, and they won’t be weak while traveling.
pli-tv-kd8:15.8.6: This is the reason I wish to give meals to the departing monks for as long as I live.

pli-tv-kd8:16.1.2: They emitted semen while dreaming and the furniture was soiled.

pli-tv-kd8:16.2.1: and the Buddha said, “That’s how it is, Ānanda.
pli-tv-kd8:16.2.2: For one who goes to sleep absentminded and heedless, semen is emitted while dreaming.
pli-tv-kd8:16.2.3: But for those monks who fall asleep mindful and heedful, this doesn’t happen.
pli-tv-kd8:16.2.4: Nor does it for ordinary people without sensual desire.
pli-tv-kd8:16.2.5: And, Ānanda, it’s impossible for a perfected one to emit semen.”

pli-tv-kd8:16.3.1: “There are these five disadvantages in going to sleep absentminded and heedless:

pli-tv-kd8:16.3.4: And there are these five benefits in going to sleep mindful and heedful:
pli-tv-kd8:16.3.5: you sleep well; you wake up feeling good; you don’t have nightmares; the gods guard you; and you don’t emit semen.
pli-tv-kd8:16.3.7: And, monks, I allow a sitting mat to protect the body, to protect the robes, and to protect the furniture.”

pli-tv-kd8:25.1.11: They said to Upananda, “We’re sharing out the Sangha’s robe-cloth. Will you accept a share?”
pli-tv-kd8:25.1.13: He then took that share too, made a large bundle of robe-cloth, and returned to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd8:25.2.1: The monks said to him, “You have much merit, Upananda, since you have been given so much robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-kd8:25.2.2: “This has nothing to do with merit.”
pli-tv-kd8:25.2.3: And he told them how he had obtained so much robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.1: “So you spent the rains residence in one place and accepted a share of the robe-cloth from somewhere else?”
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.3: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.4: “How can Venerable Upananda spend the rains residence in one place and accept a share of the robe-cloth from somewhere else?”
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.5: They told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.6: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.9: “… Foolish man, how can you spend the rains residence in one place and accept a share of the robe-cloth from somewhere else?
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.10: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.12: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.13: “You should not spend the rainy-season residence in one place and accept a share of the robe-cloth from somewhere else.
pli-tv-kd8:25.3.14: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.1: At one time Venerable Upananda spent the rains residence in two separate monasteries, thinking, “In this way I’ll get much robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.2: The monks considered, “What share of the robe-cloth should be given to Venerable Upananda?”
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.4: “Give the foolish man one person’s share.
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.5: It may be that a monk spends the rains residence in two monasteries with the intention of getting much robe-cloth.
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.6: If he spends half the time in each monastery, he should be given half a share of the robe-cloth in each.
pli-tv-kd8:25.4.7: Otherwise he should be given his share of the robe-cloth in the monastery where he spends the most time.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.0: The account of the one who was sick
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.1: At one time a monk who had dysentery
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.2: was lying in his own feces and urine.
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.3: Just then the Buddha was walking about the dwellings with Venerable Ānanda as his attendant and he came to this monk.
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.4: When he saw his condition, he approached him and said,
pli-tv-kd8:26.1.10: “Because I don’t do anything for them.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.2: “Go and get some water, Ānanda, let’s wash this monk.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.4: Then the Buddha poured the water,
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.6: Afterwards the Buddha lifted him by the head
pli-tv-kd8:26.2.7: and Ānanda by the feet, and they lay him on a bed.
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.2: “Is there a sick monk in that dwelling?”
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.9: “Because he doesn’t do anything for us.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.11: “Monks, you have no mother or father to nurse you.
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.12: If you don’t nurse one another, who will?
pli-tv-kd8:26.3.13: Whoever would nurse me should nurse those who are sick.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.1: If you have a preceptor, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.2: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.3: If you have a teacher, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.4: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.5: If you have a student, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.6: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.7: If you have a pupil, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.8: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.9: If you have a co-student, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.10: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.11: If you have a co-pupil, he should nurse you for life;
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.12: he should not go anywhere until you have recovered.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.13: If you have none of these, the Sangha should nurse you.
pli-tv-kd8:26.4.14: If you don’t nurse one who is sick, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd8:26.5.1: When a sick person has five qualities, they are hard to nurse:
pli-tv-kd8:26.5.2: they do what is detrimental for curing the sickness; they do not know the right amount in what is beneficial; they do not take their medicine; they do not accurately report the state of their illness—whether it’s getting worse, getting better, or remaining the same—to the one who is nursing and trying to help them; they are unable to bear up with bodily feelings that are painful, severe, sharp, and life-threatening.
pli-tv-kd8:26.6.1: When a sick person has five qualities, they are easy to nurse:
pli-tv-kd8:26.6.2: they do what is beneficial for curing the sickness; they know the right amount in what is beneficial; they take their medicine; they accurately report the state of their illness—whether it’s getting worse, getting better, or remaining the same—to the one who is nursing and trying to help them; they are able to bear up with bodily feelings that are painful, severe, sharp, and life-threatening.
pli-tv-kd8:26.7.1: When an attendant has five qualities, they are unsuited to nurse the sick:
pli-tv-kd8:26.7.2: they are incapable of preparing medicine; not knowing what is beneficial and what is harmful, they bring what is harmful and remove what is beneficial; they nurse the sick for the sake of worldly gain, not with a mind of kindness; they are disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they are incapable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a Dhamma talk from time to time.
pli-tv-kd8:26.8.1: When an attendant has five qualities, they are suited to nurse the sick:
pli-tv-kd8:26.8.2: they are capable of preparing medicine; knowing what is beneficial and what is harmful, they remove what is harmful and bring what is beneficial; they nurse the sick with a mind of kindness, not for the sake of worldly gain; they are not disgusted at having to clean up feces, urine, spit, or vomit; they are capable of instructing, inspiring, and gladdening the sick person with a Dhamma talk from time to time.
pli-tv-kd8:27.1.1: On one occasion two monk were traveling in the Kosalan country.
pli-tv-kd8:27.1.5: “The Buddha has praised nursing the sick,
pli-tv-kd8:27.1.6: so let’s nurse this sick monk.”
pli-tv-kd8:27.1.8: But while they were nursing him, he died.
pli-tv-kd8:27.1.9: They then took his bowl and robes and went to Sāvatthī, where they told the Buddha what had happened. He said,
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.1: “When a monk dies, the Sangha becomes the owner of his bowl and robes.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.2: Still, the nurses have been very helpful.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.3: I allow the Sangha to give the three robes and bowl to the nurses.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.4: And they should be given like this.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.5: The monk nurse should approach the Sangha and say,
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.7: Here are his three robes and bowl.’
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.8: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.9: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.11: Here are his three robes and bowl.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.12: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should give the three robes and the bowl to the nurses.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.14: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.16: Here are his three robes and bowl.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.17: The Sangha gives the three robes and the bowl to the nurses.

pli-tv-kd8:27.2.19: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.20: The Sangha has given the three robes and the bowl to the nurses.
pli-tv-kd8:27.2.21: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd8:27.5.1: On one occasion a monk with many possessions had died.
pli-tv-kd8:27.5.3: “When a monk dies, the Sangha becomes the owner of his bowl and robes.

pli-tv-kd8:28.1.0: Discussion of the prohibition against nakedness
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.1: On one occasion a naked monk went to the Buddha and said,
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.2: “In many ways, Sir, you praise fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.3: Being naked leads to all those things.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.4: It would be good if you allowed nakedness for the monks.”
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.6: “Foolish man, it’s not suitable, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.7: How can you undertake the practice of nakedness, as do the ascetics of other religions?
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.8: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.10: he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.11: “You should not undertake the practice of nakedness, as do the ascetics of other religions.
pli-tv-kd8:28.1.12: If you do, you commit a serious offense.”

pli-tv-kd8:32.1.0: Summary of eight kinds of robes
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.1: “Monks, there are these eight summaries for the giving of a robe:
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.2: someone gives within a monastic boundary; someone gives according to an agreement; someone gives where alms are prepared; someone gives to the Sangha; someone gives to both Sanghas; someone gives to a sangha that has completed the rainy-season residence; someone gives by specifying the recipients; someone gives to an individual.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.3: Someone gives within a monastic boundary:
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.4: it should be shared by all the monks within that boundary.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.5: Someone gives according to an agreement:
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.6: when a number of monasteries combine their gains, then when it’s given in one monastery, it’s given to all.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.7: Someone gives where alms are prepared: someone gives where the Sangha is constantly working.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.8: Someone gives to the Sangha: it’s to be shared out in the presence of the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.9: Someone gives to both Sanghas: even when there are many monks and just a single nun, she should be given half; even when there are many nuns and just a single monk, he should be given half.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.10: Someone gives to a sangha that has completed the rainy-season residence: it’s to be shared out by the monks who have completed the rains residence in that monastery.
pli-tv-kd8:32.1.11: Someone gives by specifying the recipients: in regard to rice porridge, a meal, non-staple food, a robe, a dwelling, or medicines.
